view.title: Intro
view.text: Recovery from mental illness and whole person wellness starts at Touchstone Mental Health where our mission is to “inspire hope, healing and well-being.” We consider each person as a whole; integrating treatment, care and resources which support a healthy mind, body, and spirit. We are a point of reference guiding clients, community members and residents toward recovery and well-being. We encourage each person to define their life goals—

physical, mental, emotional, spiritual, social, vocational and interpersonal – and we provide the tools so people achieve them. In this module you’ll have the chance to learn more about our team approach by engaging in an interactive case story about a typical Touchstone resident.

Watch the video and then click 2 on the top bar to continue.

view.title: Adult Mental Health Continuum of Care

step.title: Arriving at Touchstone
step.text: Jenna reports feeling happy that her case manager found Touchstone for her because of the number of people who work together to support her with managing her illnesses and day-to-day living, such as meals, transportation, and housekeeping. In her first few days of being at Touchstone, each person working with Jenna introduced him or herself. They talked to her about how she is at the center of her Touchstone team.
step.personnel: From my first day at Touchstone I felt safe, partly because people told me who they are and what they do, and made me feel like I am part of the team. Now I have nurses and counselors who help me when I have trouble managing my bipolar symptoms, fibromyalgia, and diabetes on my own. There are even people helping me learn how to live independently. I like to call them “Team Jenna!” A friend of mine, who also has multiple health problems, wanted to know where Team Jenna works. I told her that they are not from the same clinic. Instead, I signed releases of information so that different providers, clinics, and agencies can communicate with each other and even meet with me together at times. My apartment is beautiful. I’ve never had such a nice place that I can call my own and can keep. I don’t have to go from place to place anymore, because I can do it all here at my new home.

Right now I’m assisting Jenna with maintaining her benefits which includes keeping her health care affordable – and I can help her with general financial planning. I’m also available to help Jenna coordinate care and will make sure she knows that she should keep seeing her primary care provider and psychiatric nurse practitioner.

personnel.feedback_popup: Feedback shows after Case Manager audio completes.

step.personnel: In my first visit with Jenna, I want to hear her story and learn about her top concerns as far as her health and wellness. Then I can tell her about the options available to address these issues and together we can come up with a plan that will likely include various interventions such as mind-body connection, nutrition, movement, sleep, purpose, spirituality, environment and relationships. I can refer her to other members of the Health and Wellness team like the dietitian, fitness specialist, acupuncturist, health coach or massage therapist. I may also collaborate with her primary care provider as needed and may order some labs, supplements or medications. My focus is not on managing disease for Jenna but rather on optimizing her level of health.

step.title: Receiving a Cancer Diagonosis
step.text: Jenna’s skin cancer was caught early and is treatable. But this news has triggered some emotions that are making it difficult for her to cope with the cancer and other responsibilities in her life. She's anxious and becoming more depressed.
step.personnel: Today I met with an oncologist who told me that the red area on my shoulder is cancer. When I heard that I felt queasy and my insides did a summersault. The doctor said they can take care of it with surgery and it’s pretty routine, nothing to worry about. Nothing to worry about! Surgery sounds like something to worry about. And lots of people act like my fibromyalgia is nothing but it is something, it’s very real. I don’t know…I don’t know if I can handle this.

personnel.feedback_popup: This feedback will show after the Oncologist audio completes.

step.personnel: Of course the word “cancer” is scary, but when I explained to Jenna that her basal cell carcinoma is not life threatening and that we can treat it easily with minor surgery, she still looked stunned. When I mentioned that we should get started on treatment sooner rather than later, she didn’t say much and left rather abruptly. I’ll make a note about her response to the diagnosis and her fear about the surgery in her appointment form which goes back to Touchstone.

When I read the oncologist’s note about Jenna’s reaction to learning that she had basal cell carcinoma, I became concerned. In working with Jenna over the past four weeks I’ve learned that her anxiety and depression can become severe pretty quickly when she feels overwhelmed. I called her counselor, Julia, and she said she would contact her right away. Then, I talked to Jenna about seeing a healing touch provider to help her not feel so anxious. She agreed to give it a try and we made the appointment together.

Maria, a nurse who has been working with Jenna, mentioned that she was concerned that Jenna might be misperceiving her skin cancer as something more serious or even terminal. But when I met with Jenna, what I learned is that, in the past, she felt like her fibromyalgia pain was often just minimized because of her mental illness diagnosis. When the oncologist was trying to ease her fears about the type of cancer she has, it might have appeared to Jenna that she was downplaying the cancer which triggered some of the feelings she has when people downplay her fibromyalgia – and her fibromyalgia is very real and painful for her.

I just had my first session with Jenna. I explained the benefits and risks of healing touch and how it can help with her immune system as well as helping her manage the pain of her fibromyalgia. Jenna appreciated how relaxing the treatment was and scheduled a return visit. I will let Jenna’s counselor know that the first session went well and that I recommend she continue with a few more especially as the surgery date gets closer.

QA.title: Don't know?
QA.question: Don't know again.
QA.feedback: This is the feedback to I don't know.

QA.title: Don't know part 2?
QA.question: Don't know again. part 2
QA.feedback: This is the feedback to I don't know. part 2

step.title: Increasing Depression
step.text: Jenna’s skin cancer triggered what appears to be a major depressive episode and anxiety symptoms, nearly as bad as one she had in her twenties. Medications are an important aspect to treating Jenna’s mental illness as well as her diabetes, fibromyalgia, and now her cancer. Managing the safety and effectiveness of multiple medications is complicated and good communication among her providers is essential. Alternative treatments to medication are also an important part of Jenna’s treatment.
step.personnel: I talked to Jenna’s counselor so I know she’s been working with Jenna on taking small steps toward the things she needs to do to cope with the cancer diagnosis and manage her depressive symptoms. Jenna hasn’t been showing up at her part-time job for the past two weeks and they just fired her. Jenna’s finances are very limited, so today I met with her and she assisted me with calling the county to identify what she can do to stay on MA-EPD, a program for persons on Medical Assistance who have a limited employment-based income.

I reminded Jenna that she needs to schedule her surgery appointment, and she said to me, “I think that can wait, I have so much on my plate right now.” I explained that putting it off is not a good idea and asked her if she is worried about the procedure itself. She said, “Yes, I’m really scared, and if the cancer isn’t that bad, I don’t see why I have to rush.” I told her that I know it can be scary, but you really need to get through this next step, and I asked her if I can make the appointment for her. She agreed but doesn’t want to know when it will be until the week of so she doesn’t have to worry so long. I told her I’d attend the appointment with her. I’ll share our conversation with Julia, her counselor, and connect with her psych nurse practitioner.

Jenna has been a patient of mine for the last couple of years. Maria, her nurse, told me that Jenna was recently diagnosed with cancer and there has been an increase in anxiety and depressive symptoms. Jenna and I will have to work together to manage her symptoms and be sure the medications work for her during this added time of stress. I asked Maria to send me her current list of fibromyalgia and diabetes medications to see if there have been any changes. And before I change any prescriptions, I’ll also connect with a pharmacist to discuss drug interactions.

The psych nurse practitioner called me about some changes she’d like to make to Jenna’s current medications. I’m concerned about overwhelming Jenna with a complex medication regimen. I have some recommendations for how we can optimize Jenna’s clinical outcomes, while also simplifying her regimen. I want to make sure that when Jenna goes to fill the prescriptions there are no problems at the pharmacy with dispensing so I’ll work out any insurance requirements (such as prior authorizations) or medical assistance issues in advance. I know that Jenna is interested in using dietary supplements and herbal products. I can work with Jenna and the mental health nurse practitioner to choose agents that are from reputable manufacturers and are also safe to use with her other therapies and conditions. In the end, it’ll be important to empower Jenna by providing her with information about her options, potential risks and benefits, and other resources that might be helpful.

I met with Jenna this morning. Her nurse, Maria, emailed me, so I knew how anxious she was about the surgery. I helped her to understand that avoidance was part of a pattern common in how she relates to others and to important events in her life. Jenna said that every time she thought about the appointment she thought, “I’ll die from the treatment, and maybe I would just be better off dead now.” We talked about how the treatment might involve some pain but will help her stay healthy long term, but she doesn’t seem convinced yet. I reminded Jenna that she’s coped well before, has many supporters on her team, and she can do this!

This afternoon Jenna and a few of her neighbors participated in a gardening activity that I had planned. Jenna had shared the news about her cancer during the activity and one neighbor made a comment about how Jenna was being over dramatic and unrealistic about her skin cancer. Well, this was hard for Jenna to hear and she began crying. Other neighbors stopped gardening and offered Jenna their support, which appeared to help Jenna feel better. In fact, Jenna planted a flower and named it “hope” and said she will be by to care for and water it daily – which I noted in Jenna’s chart.

step.title: Team Meeting
step.text: One week after the gardening activity, several members of “Team Jenna” gathered to re-address her upcoming surgery appointment and Jenna’s need for this experience to be as positive as possible. The team also prepared a written care plan that includes the roles, responsibilities, and action items for each member. Jenna reported feeling less depressed after her neighbors offered support. She also said she feels less worried due to using Healing Touch to relax more regularly, and stated that the change in medications was helping too.
step.personnel: After learning the specifics about Jenna’s surgery day, I offered to go with her to the appointment. Jenna really liked this idea. In fact, she asked if I could drive her there and back so that she doesn’t get too scared and leave.

I told Jenna I would make sure that her flower was watered the day she was at her appointment. I know how committed she has been to taking care of it and I wanted her to know that it’s important to me too.

I told Jenna I could help her prepare all of the medical forms and would pack the medications that she needs to bring to the surgery. There are quite a few forms to complete and Jenna seemed relieved that I could help her.
I’m still a little worried about the surgery, but everyone at the meeting was trying hard to take care of my needs so I’m going to try hard too.

step.title: Living with Multiple Chronic Illnesses
step.text: Jenna has done better coping with stress and managing her health and other aspects of her life since having the surgery for her skin cancer. It’s an up and down process and each day is different, but being a part of the team at Touchstone has helped her to heal in many ways and increase her independence.
step.personnel: An important aspect of managing diabetes is keeping blood sugar levels stable, and stress can greatly impact those levels. The stress of the cancer news wreaked havoc with Jenna’s blood sugars and made her fibromyalgia pain much worse. It’s important for Jenna to review coping skills that have worked for her in the past to manage stressful situations that come up. I am continuing to work closely with Julia, her counselor, who is helping Jenna to create a coping skills toolbox and add to her options for the future. Of course, exercise also helps to reduce stress, and Jenna will need some guidance on this post surgery. I reached out to our fitness specialist to help her with that. I’ll work with Jenna to help her manage all of her medical conditions on an ongoing basis and will pay close attention to whether she stops taking any medications.

Jenna told me about her cancer. One of the nurses also shared the oncologist’s note about easing back into exercise after surgery so as not to put pressure on her stitches. Jenna has not exercised regularly in the past, so I decided to use her “down time” after surgery to just talk about a fitness routine and the types of things she likes to do as well as the things that will support her overall health. Getting excited about a fitness routine and making a mental commitment is half the battle. Once her stitches heal, I want her to be excited about starting.

Jenna has experienced some significant disruptions to her daily schedule and life roles. It’s important for her to take some control of her daily routine and build structure into her days now that she’s not working. This will not only keep her from further spiraling into anxiety, but will also keep her “work ready” for when she is able to return to employment.

I think it’s important for Jenna to stay connected with her peers. Several of her neighbors have continued to be supportive of her and that seems to lift Jenna’s spirits. I also want to see her continue to water and take care of her flower, as well as attend more sessions with our Healing Touch Provider.

view.title: Conclusion
view.text: </br>Being part of an integrative mental healthcare team is a unique experience. You not only have the opportunity to empower individuals living with mental illness to live healthy and productive lives, but you also have the opportunity to learn and grow professionally by interacting with a diverse group of health and wellness practitioners.

</br>Touchstone Mental Health is an organization of excellence creating innovative, person-centered care with individuals whose lives are affected by mental illness. We transform how services for mental, physical and social health intersect to achieve optimal wellness.

view.title: Intro
view.text: The Amherst H. Wilder Foundation is a nonprofit community organization that helps children, families and older adults in the greater east metro area of Saint Paul through direct service programs, research, leadership development and community building. The Wilder legacy was established by Amherst H. Wilder, a successful Saint Paul businessman, his wife Fanny Spencer Wilder and their daughter, Cornelia Day Wilder Appleby. The Wilder family willed their estate over a century ago to help the poor, sick and needy of Saint Paul, beginning a legacy of service. The Amherst H. Wilder Foundation believes that investing in people, enhancing the relationships we have with one other, and working to promote health and resilience will help create a vibrant community. Through our direct service programs, Wilder Research, and community building, we are helping people reach their full potential.

The purpose of this educational module is to help you better understand our unique approach to mental health services. Click Resources on the top bar for an overview of the following: Trauma-Informed Care Children and Family Mental Heath Southeast Asian Services In this module you will learn more about Wilder’s approach to children and family mental healthcare by engaging in an interactive case story.

Please watch the introductory video and then click “2” on the top bar to continue.

view.title: Story
view.text: <b>Jason is a 7-year-old boy referred to Wilder because teachers would like him evaluated for ADHD. Jason has all of the “classic” signs of ADHD. He can’t seem to sit still, finds it hard to concentrate, becomes aggressive with other kids, on occasion hits his teachers, and has a hard time when he changes classrooms, for example, going from recess to science, from science to reading, and so on. It often takes him up to half an hour to calm down, and by then, the class is typically almost over. Jason struggles with boundaries and often becomes emotionally distressed if told “no,” sometimes running out of the classroom or crying. Jason has also been diagnosed with asthma, and when he becomes upset, the crying can trigger his asthma symptoms. Jason is really bright and despite what appears to be ADHD, when he’s calm, does well academically. He is also engaging, and most people, including other kids, really like him.

stop.text: Jason attends school in the neighborhood and is in the 1st grade. He likes school, especially recess and lunch.
stop.person: Jason is a very sweet, likeable boy. All the other kids and teachers like him when he’s having a good day. I know he’s smart, but he just can’t seem to sit still long enough to learn. His restlessness and getting out of his seat disturbs other students. The more I try to help him control his behaviors, the more frustrated he gets, and then it escalates from there. Sometimes it even triggers an asthma attack and he has to use his inhaler. I can tell he always feels so bad about getting upset.

I can tell that there’s more going on for Jason than just the typical ADHD, but I don’t know what else to call it. His teacher contacted me because she was concerned about his aggressive behaviors. When I’ve talked to Jason and his mom, it sounds like the family has been through some really tough times.

I like Miss Wilson, but my favorite person at school is Mr. Lee. He lets me go in his office and play with his toys. It helps me when I can’t control my body. I’m trying to be good, but sometimes my body just won’t listen to me.

I’d like to spend time talking to Jason’s teacher so that I can learn more about what happens at school and how it’s structured. For example, does he have more issues in the cafeteria at lunchtime or in really noisy environments? Does he have issues when the class activities are seated at the desk tabletop or is it harder when people are talking and the environment is louder? I’d also like to speak with Mr. Lee about what he sees when Jason visits him. Jason says he likes to see Mr. Lee and I wonder if the quieter, less stimulating space is a factor of this.

QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: The team of providers gather information from mom and one another to better understand Jason and his needs.
stop.person: Jason’s my little helper at home. I know Jason is smart, and I don’t understand why he’s acting this way at school. I don’t see this at home. He has a hard time sometimes when I tell him no and sometimes he does need to cry it out but ADHD? I just don’t understand what’s going on at school and why he’s having such a hard time.

mom sounds confused about why Jason is having a much harder time at school than at home. I’d like to talk to her about his ability to pay attention to tasks and how well he can focus at home, at church, and in other environments because learning more about what Jason’s behaviors are like across all these environments will help me tease out if his behaviors are school related, home related or something else. This will give the team of professionals who care about Jason a clearer picture of what’s going on with him and the impact these behaviors have on his physical wellbeing and his asthma.

The Psychiatric Advanced Practice nurse contacted me about Jason and the concerns at school. I’ll work with the team by talking with mom to learn where Jason is at with things like self-care and willingness to do chores at home. I’d like to learn about all of the different factors that are impacting his ability to participate successfully in his ”occupations,” meaning school, self care, play, interaction with peers, interaction with siblings, other family and neighbors. If there’s great disparity in the way he participates and interacts in the different settings of his life, it could help me understand some of the underlying issues of Jason’s challenges.

We will want to discuss with mom if Jason uses any supplements or home, herbal or alternative remedies and how these might affect how he feels. Herbals and supplements can have strong effects and, if Jason does take any, I can help sort out the benefits as well as the risks to them. Jason’s case manager and I talked last week about insurance and how to provide help to pay for his asthma medications including his inhaler and any nutritional supplements.
stop.reading: It’s always helpful to consider a situation from someone else’s perspective, etc. etc. For example, Miss Wilson is obviously concerned about Jason, but remember, she has 30 other children in her classroom and ... QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: Despite the unsafe neighborhood, mom has found people who understand and support her and her family.
stop.person: I was desperate and this was the only place we could afford. It’s a beautiful duplex – not a dump like some of places we’ve stayed, and here, Jason has his own space. I just wish we weren’t in such a bad neighborhood. I know that there are gangs around and I’m constantly terrified that they’ll try to get my kids, or try to influence them somehow or that they’ll get caught in the middle of things. While Jason’s young, I’m going to do my best to get us out of here and someplace else so that doesn’t become a problem. For now, I’m just really pushing the kids to be safe and for them to know that they can’t be out in the neighborhood without me.

Jason and his family have just started coming, but already they are committed members of our congregation. I know that that family has been through some bad times, but I’m glad we are able to support them here. I know it’s hard for mom to trust, but I think we’re getting there slowly, day by day. In fact mom and Jason have joined one of our support groups here that I think will help her to know that she isn’t alone and that other people are here to help her and Jason.

Mommy says we can’t go out because there are bad people around by our new house. One time I saw some people beating on others. It was really scary. I don’t want anyone beating on me. It’s hard for me to sleep at night because I hear the police cars all the time. Mommy says at least we have a place to live. She is right. I do like this better than staying at the shelter. At least I have my own room and someplace to play.

I’ve known Jason and his mom now for a few months. His mom is really trying, but it’s hard to with little ones when you’re still struggling yourself. So I go over, I check in, see if she wants me to take the kids so that she can get a break, and she checks in on me and makes sure the kids come over now and then to help get my mail. Jason comes over when his mom goes to her church meetings. When he comes here he has fun playing with the toys I have for him. But, he sure has a hard time letting his mommy out of his sight. He cries and pulls on her clothes to get her to stay. Once she is gone, I give him a snack and he seems to feel better.

QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: Jane, a therapist at Wilder, helps mom to understand possible connections between Jason’s past and his behavior at school and other places.
stop.person: I’m learning to understand how overwhelmed Jason has been and that how he’s acting is because of all the things he’s seen and been through. I didn’t think that he’d remember that stuff from when he was a baby, but Jane is helping me understand that maybe he reacts like this because of trauma. Jane says there’s a lot we can do to help him continue to be stronger and I’m glad. I’m more determined than ever to figure out what I have to do to help him get over the past and how I can protect him from now on.

Jason and his mom really have a wonderful relationship and I see how well mom is able to help calm and coach him when given the right support and tools. Mom is really getting that Jason’s ADHD-like behaviors may really be a response to the trauma experienced in his life such as witnessing abuse between mom and dad, financial stressors, neighborhood safety issues, multiple family moves, and the sudden death of his dad, which the family has not really talked about. She herself is keeping a pretty tight lid on her emotions and completely avoids the topic of his dad, something I know Jason has a lot of feelings and thoughts about – it comes out in his play all the time. The challenge for me is how to help mom figure out how her own trauma responses are impacting how she is helping Jason. Mom has been so supportive of Jason and my fear is that as we get closer to the traumas experienced that are shared by mom, it may get harder for her to stay engaged as she’s made it clear that she’s not ready to go there herself. I’m also working with Jason’s school and other service providers to try and figure out a different plan for him at school to help with some of the things that seem really hard for him. Making these accommodations and watching Jason’s response is the least invasive approach. If there is no change in a month, we should re-evaluate.

My favorite time is when I see Jane. We play and laugh and my mom plays with us too. Jane tells me that I’m not a bad boy. She said that someday, I’ll learn to help my body and brain listen to each other so that they can be friends. Mommy comes and has fun too. I like it when she laughs.

QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: Providers work interprofessionally by discussing Jason’s case in team meetings and using the electronic medical record to communicate with each other.
stop.person: Jason’s primary care provider informed us that Jason has asthma and is taking some regularly scheduled medications. As a team, we can work with mom to ensure that all medications in the household are safely and properly stored. Jason is only 7 years old, and I agree with the team to try alternative approaches to work with his behaviors at school. ADHD is a possible diagnosis and we need to explore other reasons for his school problems. Also, medications for ADHD can worsen other symptoms. I will be in close conversations with Jason’s care providers to ensure that any medication therapy is both safe and effective.

Jason is a delightful boy who can focus when he is highly engaged. We’ve been working on self-regulation strategies and are using the Alert Program ‘How does your engine run?’ teaching Jason to “self-assess” so he can be better prepared to participate in classroom activities at school. His therapist, teacher and I are working together to incorporate sensory activities to prepare Jason for productive work. And, we’ll begin working with mom to teach her strategies from the Alert program.

My job is to help mom, Jason, and other service providers assess what services are going well, what aren’t, and what additional services I can put in place to support Jason. Sometimes this means I have to really support mom and help her figure out things so that it’s not so overwhelming. I also help all of the folks involved communicate with each other and with Jason and mom so that we’re always on the same page about what direction we’re moving and how we’re supporting Jason and mom and each other. I can partner more closely with mom helping her manage her own feelings of guilt and helping her understand what she can do to work with Jason at home. I also feel like my part in this is to really support mom so that she feels like someone is really listening to her – she’s got some amazing strengths, and the information and collaboration could really be working both ways, not just from the providers to her. She can also share her wisdom to inform what they are doing with Jason.
stop.reading: It’s always helpful to consider a situation from someone else’s perspective, etc. etc. For example, Miss Wilson is obviously concerned about Jason, but remember, she has 30 other children in her classroom and ... QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: Providers continue to work together to identify approaches and problem solving techniques that Jason can use at school and at home.
stop.person: From my observation, and hearing from the rest of the team, mom has a wonderful calming effect on Jason. We’ve seen her intervene when he is anxious and having difficulty with self-control and she helps him to regain control. We can work with Jason’s school staff to identify how some of these approaches can be brought into the school to help him when he becomes emotionally distressed.

We’re working with Jason to focus on small steps and asking for help when he’s frustrated, when he makes mistakes, or when a particular step seems too hard. A concern at this point is his response to feedback and some of the overreactions that occur with limits, like being told “No.” We are helping him learn to problem solve when he encounters difficulties with the materials, and to stay with the task in the time he has allotted.

It does appear that there is more going on with Jason than things directly related to ADHD. Mom’s identification of Jason as her little helper leads to additional questions about school and home environmental factors and their impact on his ability to be successful at home and at school. The Wilder care team, teachers, and other community partners will continue to work with Jason and his family to further understand all of the factors impacting him.

QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

stop.text: Incorporating holistic approaches like proper diet and nutrition are important to mom and the rest of the team.
stop.person: mom asked that I visit with her about Jason’s diet and nutrition. Jason doesn’t have any food allergies and he has a good appetite! Healthy diets are important for brain development, mood, attention, and overall feeling of well-being. mom enjoys cooking vegetables and traditional Asian foods, which are high in omega 3 fatty acids. We discussed the importance of limiting processed foods and foods that have refined sugar and high fructose corn syrup. Jason’s family accesses food from the local food shelf, and mom doesn’t understand all the directions of how to prepare some of the food her family receives. We talked about how she can prepare healthy meals using food that she gets from the food shelf. I think her case manager and neighbors can make sure she receives good food for her family. I would like to support mom in her attempts to have family meals together with no TV or electronic distractions in order to foster positive social interactions at meal time. I’ll work with Jason’s care providers to provide holistic care for Jason.

In my family, medications are usually the last thing we think about. I’m glad I could talk with the nutritionist because her ideas fit closely with what I’m already trying to include in Jason’s daily life. For example, I try to limit the use of his inhaler at home by keeping things as calm as possible so he doesn’t have an attack. But, if he doesn’t get better and needs some medications, I am pretty sure that his psychiatric nurse practitioner will talk to me about the medicines that will help him the most and she’ll watch for side effects.

I appreciated learning from Sandra, the nutritionist, that mom is intentional about preparing healthy foods. Also, I was glad to hear Jason doesn’t have any food or seasonal allergies that could be affecting his mood and behaviors. We’ll also assess his diet for caffeine, and follow up with his mom about limiting processed foods. In order to help control his asthma symptoms, I want to find out if Jason is exposed to smoking at home, at Mrs. V’s house, his neighbor, or anywhere else.

Speaking of food, accessing healthy food for nutritious meals is sometimes a real issue for Jason’s family. I can continue to work with mom to help her access the food her family needs so that Jason can be successful in school, community, and home.

Our family has gone through so much. I know Jason sometimes does struggle with frustration, paying attention, and staying in control of his body. I love him so much, and it’s hard to trust that professionals will really take the time to listen to our story and our needs. Now I feel that he has a team of people who will listen, understand, and will see what a wonderful boy Jason is. I’m so thankful for the team at Wilder who will help us!

QA.title: What Would You Do?
QA.question: How might things have turned out differently if the nurse had not contacted the pharmacist?
QA.feedback: Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback. Lorem ipsum, here is some feedback.

view.title: Conclusion
view.text: </br>Behavioral and mental health issues can be difficult to understand and navigate. At Wilder we help families understand the healing process from diagnosis to treatment and everything in between. We work with the entire family to reinforce skills and tools to support people at home and we connect families to helpful resources.

</br>We do this by learning about each family’s cultural perspectives on what will be helpful. We are constantly adapting our bicultural bilingual services to adapt to emerging needs as new cultural groups move to our community.
